Reviewed by: Rabid Reads.I didn’t read the original version of this trilogy, so I can’t give an opinion as to whether the tweaks are an improvement, but what I can say is that I loved Shannon Mayer’s BOUND! It’s a pseudo zombie story that follows a couple who’s love overcomes insurmountable odds. It’s corny, and does require a bit of a leap vis-à-vis why only Mara & Bastian’s connection trumps all where as other twosomes “turn”. But, it’s written in such a way that it’s next to impossible to put down, and makes you want to believe in unicorns.Phase two of the end-of-the-civilization involved the army taking over, the abuse that comes along with the government going belly-up, and rumours of a cure. Unsurprisingly, several factions pop up in the wake of the Nevermore disaster, and Mara & Bastien get caught right in the middle due to their unusual abilities. We meet some pretty scary people along the way, namely Vincent and Donovan, and the author had no qualms about highlighting how truly deprived humanity can become when society as we know it crumbles. BOUND will make you cry uncle!BOUND was not your typical zombie story. ~4.5 Stars

The storyline continues directly after Sundered. Considering the length of the book, both of them, probably together with the third installment of this trilogy, would have made a decently sized full novel. The story of Mara and Sebastian continues, with a plot twist bringing them into contact with other survivors and a possible cure for the Nevermore drug.The first book was entertaining enough, despite some minor flaws. But Bound, although the plot idea was good, was pretty weak in terms of storyline development. It felt rushed, ideas were often just hinted at. It could have done with more depth into the story as well as the characters. Some of those were little more than caricatures.Bottomline, not bad. But could have done with some fleshing out. The characters stayed a little flat and the whole thing left me unsatisfied. I am mildy curious about the ending to the trilogy, but considering the length (or lack thereof) I am not interested enough to spend more money on it.

The second book in Mayer's Nevermore Trilogy Bound is another fast pace and fun read. The romance continues between Sebastian and Mara. Their love amazes me. Once again the turmoil this couple goes through is heart breaking but their love for one another never falters. In this book we are with Mara as she struggles to survive the Nevermore out break. I was happy to find out that this book flowed seamlessly from the first. I bought it when I bought the first and was glad that I had it to move immediately on to. Bound left me hoping for Dauntless which is to be released at the end of October. Thankfully not to far away. If your looking for a great romance, that is a fast read and will capture your heart, I suggest the Nevermore Trilogy!Thanks Shannon Mayer :)

I received this book in exchange for an honest review, which​ I take very seriously.In the 2nd book of The Nevermore Trilogy, we learn that Sebastian almost lets go of what remains of his human side, but Mara is relentless in reminding him of it and not losing it. We learn that the Nevermores can and do communicate with each other and the hoard as a whole, like a hive almost.We learn that a few Nevermores cling to the last bits of their humanity, like Scout. And we learn that the military-ish people, dressed in fatigues, they come and tell Mara that it just isn't safe and she MUST go with them. At first she resists, fearing for Sebastian and losing him, so they basically take her. Someone follows.These "military-esque" men are somewhat whipped into submission by their lead asshats, the first of which is named Vincent. He takes perverse pleasure in torturing and makes no exceptions on who's on the what love can endure other end of his devices. This second book is about what love can endure and what it probably shouldn't, yet still does.

I enjoyed the ongoing saga of Sebastian and Mara in this sequel to "Sundered". Their situation has worsened in this second book but Mara still fights to save both her husband and her unborn baby. Not so much against the creatures called Nevermores, this time her battles are more with her own kind - the humans. Ms Mayer has a unique way of creating characters and telling a story and I hope she's around for a very long time. How she ever came up with the premise for this trilogy, I can't imagine. It's quite uniquely different from anything I've read before and I can't wait for the last in the series.

This 3 book series was a nice change of pace for me. I typically read a lot of romance novels and this book was different. It's a love story all twisted up into a world of zombie-ish monsters. I have already recommended this series to a few of my friends. It's a different twist from the typical love story and the characters are ones you won't forget. You will even be surprised by some of the characters that you will fall in love with. It's and easy and fun read if you're looking for something a little different.

Another great read!The story picks nicely where it had been left in the first book of the series. As smoothly and readably as before, ‘Bound’ takes us into a different, unexpected direction. Mara chose love!  Mara and Sebastian’s story is one of those tales that true love really does conquer all.   Even a drug that turns you feral to the point of cannibalistic can’t defeat true love.  Yet Mara and Sebastian aren’t finished being tested.  When they are captured by rogue band of paramilitary things go downhill fast.  Mara’s love for Sebastian is put to the ultimate test and her life along with Sebastian’s and their unborn child are put on the line by a crazed power hungry nut job. I didn’t love book two as much as I instantly fell in love with book one.  Not really sure why.  Mara continues to grow into a strong, resourceful and dare I say almost Kick ass chick, well, almost, she is getting close.  The relationship between her and Sebastian is one I love and I can’t wait to read the third installment, Dauntless....Sara http://www.boundlessbookreviews.comhttps://www.facebook.com/BBReviews

This is the second in the Nevermore series. This book had a scene that moved me to tears, so do have a hanky ready. I found out more about the Nevermores and the drug that created them in this middle book. I also discovered some human monsters.The things I liked about this book were the growth of Mara and the evolution of the Nevermores. These are not your typical zombies and they are changing and becoming more complex. Mara is stepping up and becoming a strong and compassionate person.If you like paranormal romances or zombie books, start with Sundered and continue on to Bound. I think you'll find it rewarding. As the book ended on a cliffhanger, I am eagerly awaiting the next book.

Although I enjoyed the first story, when the military (or what people believe should be passed for the military) show up, I'm immediately turned of. It's one of the reason I don't really read this genre. I would have enjoyed it more had Mara and Bas stayed out on their farm with their dogs trying to survive. They seemed to have a good thing going adjusting and then it was shattered by the introduction of madmen. I know it makes for suspenseful reading and such but I just can't get with it. Although the writing is great, I just couldn't deal with how things were progressing. It was out of the fire and into the frying pan. Still a big fan of Ms. Mayer's work but just not a fan of this trilogy as much as Rylee, Lark, and the Celtic books.

This is a Quickie Review. For the full review, please visit The Romanceaholic.Expected Release Date: September 14, 2011 (Available Now!)Publisher: Self PublishedImprint: N/AAuthor’s Website: http://www.shannonmayer.com/My Source for This Book: Amazon.comPart of a Series: Yes, Book 2 Nevermore Zombie Apocalypse TrilogySeries Best Read In Order: YESSteam Level: SteamyOfficial Blurb:Nevermore Trilogy Book IIRumours and whispers of a cure have reached Mara’s ears and hope that has been denied for so long begins to grow once more. But, if she is to find the cure, to help Sebastian, she must face down a whole new set of dangers. A sadistic army General whose hatred knows no bounds.A brilliant scientist whose love for his lost wife drives him to madness.And a new pack of Nevermores . . .Sensitive readers should know going in that there is a child death in this story.While this one did end in what I would consider to be a "cliff-hanger", I do have to admit that it was a much better stopping point than that of the previous installment, Sundered.Even having not read the final installment, Dauntless (expected release October 31, 2011), I have to say my very strong opinion thus far is that the entire series should probably be consolidated into a single, longer story and given a higher price point. While I understand that the current price of ninety-nine cents for Sundered, and right at three dollars for Bound, is a definite selling point for readers unfamiliar with the author, the fact that this book picks up literally a sentence after the last one left off makes it virtually impossible for readers unfamiliar with the series to really get the full benefit of the story. While the general gist of the history of the apocalypse is covered, as is the relationship between Mara and Sebastian, I do think that some readers who did not read Sundered will be highly disappointed with just how obvious it is that the first book is an integral part of this one.That said, I would still recommend both Sundered and Bound to any fan of zombie apocalypse fans, especially those who prefer a strong romantic theme. Gritty, violent, tragic, and terrifying, this whole series also manages to be touching, romantic, and at times, even sexy (which let me tell you, is an achievement considering the hero is a zombie). Just make certain that you pick up the first book before attempting this one and you won't have any problems.I am actually very excited to have found this author. Even with the slightly-campy feel to the initial premise, her skill in creating believable characters and writing both action and love scenes is truly much more than I've experienced in a self-published author in quite some time. I am very anxiously awaiting the final installment on Halloween, and can't wait to see what becomes of Mara, Sebastian, Scout, Buck, and the others.Recommended for fans of fresh takes on the zombie apocalypse trope, of normal people surviving on their wits, and of a love that not even a zombie infection can stop.A very solid 4.5/5 Stars

I received an ARC of this book and this is my honest opinion. This is part two of a trilogy. Mara and Bastian are trying to adjust to their new reality. They are wondering how much longer they will be able to be together. If that wasn't enough, the military gets involved and Mara and Bastian have to fight to survive and for each other. This series shows that the 'monster' isn't always the obvious one. Sometimes humans are much more dangerous than any so called 'monster'.

Bound continues where Mara and Sebastian's story left off in 
Sundered
 and while their location has changed to a secret military encampment, their adventure is far from over. The action and danger does not let up, and is a daily part of their lives, only it is not just the Nevermores, but other humans with invested interests who pose a threat. Fearing that she is losing Sebastian to the Nevermore drug, Mara dares to hope that rumours of a cure are true and is willing to risk anything to save him. With Sebastian more Nevermore than human, Mara feels more alone than ever. She only has her survival instincts, a little bit of luck and most important of all her belief in her and Bastian's love to depend on. Never has their love been more important and it is about to be tested time and time again, with conflicting feelings and forces from within and out. Mara gets her time to shine and her need to survive is not just for herself and Bastian anymore, but for the life growing inside her. Amidst a world gone mad, friends become enemies and enemies become friends. Scout, a Nevermore is an unlikely friend but one who continues to show his allegiance to Mara and Bastian. He is an anomaly within the Nevermores and gives hope that they can retain some of their humanity, while some humans can lack this. The introduction of Burns, a young and impressionable soldier is a great contrast to Marks, a seasoned man, experienced with love and loss. These two men are so different and yet similar in how they help Mara, thus showing their humanity. What really appeals to me was seeing Mara and Sebastian's love develop in a whole new way. Their communication relies heavily on actions and small nuances rather than words. Their love bounds them and these emotions are what keeps Sebastian human. With her life on the line, and facing the likes of Vincent and Donavan, Mara is placed in situations that allows her to grow a backbone and have to make tough decisions. Some scenes are graphic but brief, showing that it's a dog eat dog world where the fittest and smartest survive. No longer the sweet, wallowing self that she was a few mere months ago, Mara learns that morals are not always enough to survive. What never wavers is her belief in Bastian and their love and that is what keeps me rooting for her and Sebastian.Bound is a short and riveting story that I finished in a day. I wasn't surprised at the cliffhanger in the end and will be looking forward to Dauntless to see what awaits Mara and Sebastian.

Mara and Bastian are captured by the military at their home and taken to a prison camp where Mara is told she has to train the monsters to obey her like Bastian, so they can be used for military purposes. Vincent wants to use an army of monsters to attack his enemy who is working on a cure. Not trusting Vincent, Mara is convinced that they must escape or die.I certainly didn't like this book as much as the first one in the series. I was still interested in the relationship between Mara and Bastian but I also questioned why Mara decided to restart a sexual relationship with him without knowing if the virus was going to damage her. Overall, Mara wasn't very smart in this book. Spying on Vincent so blatantly was dumb and could have led to them both being killed. But the thing that really infuriated me was Mara deciding she was attracted to the first soldier who was kind to her, which makes her supposed undying love for Bastian seem like a bit of a joke. It ruined the interest I had in the unconventional relationship between Mara and Bastian.Vincent wasn't really a character that greatly interested me. Even when we are shown why he is such an asshat and why he is obsessed with finding the cure, he still feels like the big evil cartoon bad guy. In fact most of the military men in this book are power hungry asshats who annoyed me. I did continue to like Scout though. He sort of reminds me of the boy Roach who lived inside the walls in the film The People under the Stairs. The plot for me was a bit on the weak side. The military just happened to pass by Mara's house in time to see her interact with Bastian and suddeny come to grab them both? Super evil military men fight over an experimental cure? Our poor heroes caught in the middle? I wasn't greatly convinced and this is more of a 2/2.5 book. I have the whole series in one paperback so I did read on to book 3 but hopes were not high.

I received an ARC of this book and I also purchased a copy and here is my review:I enjoyed reading Bound... the struggle and fight for Love between Sebastian and Mara has never faulted... there love stayed stronger then ever even when Mara discovered that she was with child at the end of book 1 and Sebastian became more protective... Even Sebastian was a Nevermore he stilled loved his wife and remembered her as to be his mate... Scout the ever devoted Nevermore that would guard the gate when ever Sebastian could not be there. Fire the strong and fierce young girl that wanted Sebastian but Sebastian always told her No.. Mara was his mate and life line to humanity... that is all from book one...I enjoyed how in Bound the love that Bastian (Sebastian) has for Mara.. and Mara's ability to remain strong is admirable even when forced with certain issues that happen when a certain Captain tries to make advances... she tells him I belong to Sebastian and that Sebastian was her husband even if he was a Nevermore. She loved him no matter what condition he was in.There was a group of Military want-a-bees that came along and told Mara that it wasn't safe for her to be out where she was by herself.. to me they were the monsters... specially Vincent he was cruel and fed off the cruelty that he poured onto the Nevermores.. there was actually 2 people with in that group of men that were decent and that was the Captain and a young teenager..but all in all I loved reading Bound.. and as I stated it shows a love that can never be destroyed through a time of crisis ...in Mara's and Sebastian's thoughts...There is only one way to save us both. I am forced to unearth and embrace the dark side of my heart. I must decide who is the more dangerous enemy; the Nevermores or what remains of mankind.I am bound to fight as though I am one of the monsters I hoped I’d never become.if you want to know more you need to read Bound...

description: They were promised weight loss, the cure for Cancer, Parkinson’s Disease and infertility; they were promised hope. The side effects were anything but hopeful. Mara faces seemingly insurmountable obstacles and adversities as she works feverishly to free Sebastian from the holds which bind him. Her refusal to abandon him, and his refusal to let her slip away, keep them fighting to be reunited. Fears escalate and dangers destroy their beliefs, but they cling to their love and find strength in each other even when separated. Mara and Sebastian manage to face each act of violence, each tragedy, and terrifying sight with a strength which won’t bend to any confrontation
